video.title: HTML Tutorial - Website Crash Course for Beginners (2021)
video.description:
Learn the basics of HTML in this crash course.

✏️ This course was developed by Beau Carnes.

🐈 cats.jpg: https://cdn.freecodecamp.org/youtube/html-course/cats.jpg
🍝 lasagna.jpg: https://cdn.freecodecamp.org/youtube/html-course/lasagna.jpg
💻 Code: https://github.com/freeCodeCamp/cdn/blob/main/build/youtube/html-course/index.html

🔗 Sign up for Hostinger here:  https://www.hostinger.com/getstarted

🎉 Thanks to Hostinger for providing a grant that made this course possible.

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (00:00) Introduction
⌨️ (01:38) Choosing a code editor
⌨️ (04:27) Basic HTML file
⌨️ (05:02) Elements and Tags
⌨️ (07:05) Headers
⌨️ (08:34) Paragraphs
⌨️ (09:55) Comments
⌨️ (10:45) Content Area Tags
⌨️ (13:10) Images
⌨️ (16:00) Links
⌨️ (19:54) Unordered Lists
⌨️ (22:08) Ordered Lists
⌨️ (24:24) Forms and Input Elements
⌨️ (36:45) Div Elements
⌨️ (38:57) Footer Section
⌨️ (41:06) Head Section
⌨️ (41:27) Website Title
⌨️ (42:23) Deploying Website with Hostinger

🎉 Thanks to our Champion and Sponsor supporters:
👾 Wong Voon jinq
👾 hexploitation
👾 Katia Moran
👾 BlckPhantom
👾 Nick Raker
👾 Otis Morgan
👾 DeezMaster
👾 Treehouse
👾 AppWrite

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: PoppinCorn
topLevelComment.text: been doing html for a couple days now, and i already learned a lot, and it's definitely one of the easier languages to pick up on considering I already know LUA very fluently. if you're looking into using this alongside JS and CSS, I highly recommend!

topLevelComment.author: Mathew Wiseman
topLevelComment.text: Amazing, never seen used or had any clue what html was,  now this is a 45 min teaching video, but actually took me a solid 12-14 hours to fully understand and do everything you do in this video, can do your full starter training from start to finish now without watching anything with my own ideas! Ty so much for your help with html. Keep up the good work!

topLevelComment.author: lynn45
topLevelComment.text: Quick Question: Why would someone use HTML rather than, say, a more user-friendly option to create web sites, such as Word Press? (I know this is an HTML course, and it's great, but I'm just curious why one would choose a more difficult process of creating a web site from the ground up using HTML rather than just using Word Press).

replies.author: CweaseGaming
replies.text: People who want to be web developers have to learn html, CSS, and javascript as a minimum. From there, some will go on to learn backend stuff using java, python, etc, along with some Database stuff (basic SQL) or work on front end and focus on some frameworks like React, Angular, or Vue

replies.author: Chaitanya Rajesh
replies.text:
@ValentinoW3 Okay, makes sense, as if both can be learnt here

Aprijita, if you want to learn AI, then join a bootcamp or a college 

Don't keep on fiddling with programming languages without plans because this gonna take you nowhere

Telling you from my own experience, the faster you get focused on something, the faster you learn it

Also, if you are a beginner, take a bird's eye view on every opportunity before deciding what you really want to do

I think we should give people specific advices, general motivation stuff doesn't take people anywhere, you know 😅

replies.author: ValentinoW3
replies.text:
@Chaitanya Rajesh You don't understand the situation. Aprajita wants to learn pyhton and AI, so I say, that learning python can lay a good foundation for doing AI, since you can do AI with python. So Aprajita can learn python, which he/she wants to learn and then can learn AI a bit easier. 

You seem to think Aprajita only wants to learn AI and that I tell Aprajita that he should first learn python. That is not the case. 

Or maybe to make you understand the situation, I will reformulate what Aprajita said and what you said in one of your comments using your math and programming example.

Aprajita: ...I think I can learn programming, robotics, math, quantum computing.

You: Basically, learning math for programming is like learning math for programming, but that person is not here to learn math, right?

Read your translated comment out loud and then Aprajita's comment out loud a few times until you realize that Aprajita definitely wants to learn 'math' AND 'programming'.

replies.author: Chaitanya Rajesh
replies.text:
@ValentinoW3 I meant that a masters degree in math is not required to learn programming, for I am a school going student and still learning programming

Suppose anybody learns js or C++, and wants to switch to AI, the language needed there could be learnt in weeks if not days. 

If somebody wants to learn AI, they should just start learning AI, and not waste time collecting prerequisites for it.

What if the course that person takes teaches code in swift, so if the person enters now, he wont have to overthink about what will be needed and he could directly learn what will be needed during the course itself, saving a lot of his/her time.

replies.author: ValentinoW3
